titlestmt.subtitle: Papers, 1945-1997, of Kurt Vonnegut at the Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana

change.item: Second legitimate version of this electronic finding aid. Revised to incorporate Elizabeth's suggestions. Includes LMC number, spacing corrections, and other minor changes.
Parentheses were added within container lists to separate physical descriptions from unit titles and dates.
Changes made to improve appearance (added spaces, periods after titles).
Nested titles for a more streamlined look.
Revised LMC number to reflect manuscripts division shifting
EAD id changed from InU-Li-LMC1860 to InU-Li-VAA1301.
File name changed from vonnegut3 to InU-Li-VAA1301
Box 16, Folder 1: Folder name changed from "Mark Train's House..." to "At Mark Twain's House..."

Box 9: folder 23-24: "Mother Night (1962). Galley proof of Mother Night (re-issued in hardback 1967); mock-up of trade edition" Changed to ... folders 23-"25: Mother Night (1962) Galley proof of Mother Night; mock-up of trade edition; introduction for 1966 Harper & Row hardback edition"

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.repository: Lilly Library (Indiana University, Bloomington) Lilly Library Indiana University 1200 E. Seventh St. Bloomington, IN 47405-5500 Phone: 812-855-2452 Fax: 812-855-3143 Email: liblilly@indiana.edu
did.abstract: Consists of the papers of novelist Kurt Vonnegut, born in 1922.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Prior arrangements are not necessary before coming to the Library, however, patrons from out of town are encouraged to communicate with the Library in advance of their visits to ascertain availability of materials.
Photocopying permitted only with permission of the Curator of Manuscripts, Lilly Library

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Vonnegut mss., Lilly Library, Indiana University, Bloomington, Indiana

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Consists of the papers of novelist Kurt Vonnegut, born in 1922.

Much of the general correspondence is from colleagues, friends and fans. Along with major works the Writings section contains screenplays, teleplays, play scripts and many short stories and articles. The Farber files are those of Vonnegut's agent and lawyer Donald C. Farber. They consist of contracts, correspondence and notes concerning translation, performance, and publication rights and permissions. The Publishing Records include royalty reports, contracts and items related to the publication of his works. Miscellaneous items include: awards and trophies, artwork, family related materials, school papers, photographs, and clippings.

arrangement.p: The collection is organized into the following series: I. General correspondence; II. Writings; III. Farber files; IV. Publishing records; V. Miscellaneous.

scopecontent.p: The general correspondence is mostly with Kurt Vonnegut and is divided into an alphabetical file, rejection letters and a chronological file. Correspondence with Donald C. Farber concerning contracts, translation, performance, and publication rights and permissions are filed in the Farber files. Occasionally letters were left with related writings or in other miscellaneous sections.

did.unittitle: Arranged alphabetically with occasional letters from Vonnegut filed with correspondent. Mostly with colleagues and friends.

Correspondence includes fan letters, invitations to speak, or regarding various projects, 1955-1978, bulk 1971-1994

note.p: Arranged chronologically.
See also: Farber files

scopecontent.p: Organized into the following sections: major works; reviews; short stories and articles; speeches. A few letters to Vonnegut from a publisher or editor are filed with manuscripts.
Includes books, play scripts, screenplays, television scripts, and librettos. Arranged alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Adam. Typescript of screenplay adapted by Robert Bassing, second draft June 28, 1954
Screenplay adapted from short story by Tom Cotter
Teleplay adapted by Stan Daniels from short story
Typescript of synopsis and play script
Between Time and Timbuktu ...a musical. Book and lyrics by Andrew Barrett, music by Neil Ginsberg (Based on the works of Vonnegut). Typescript of play; program
Photocopy of the final corrected typescript, 319 pages

Breakfast in Bethlehem: A one-act play for children at Christmastime. Four typescript copies, ca. 20p. each; four mimeograph copies, 8p. each. Contains some correspondence. Published as "The First Christmas Morning" inBetter Homes and Gardens . Dec. 1962
Original title: Goodbye, Blue Monday. Corrected typescript drafts of various sections1973
Vonnegut's carbon copy of his final project for the Program in Creative Writing at the University of Iowa, titled: Goodbye, Blue Monday: The Autograph of a Pontiac dealer in the American Middle-West

Typescript. Corrected in autograph, with Vonnegut's original line drawings throughout. Large unpublished section with drawings. Additional typescript, not corrected, perhaps from earlier or later drafts
First draft of screenplay by Paul Golding and Peter Bergman
Stageplay adapted by Robert Egan. Typescript
A play for seven actors, by Bruce Pribram 1977
The Chemistry Professor. (based on Jekyll and Hyde story). Play, 1978 (see also: Shilling Shocker)1978
Class of '45. Skit for "peace project." 2 copies
D.P.. Carbon typescript of play, with corrections; teleplay

Typescript, corrected in autograph. Labeled "Finished ms."
Photocopy of corrected typescript. Labeled "Summer 1981 revise xerox."

The Euphio Question. Screenplay adapted by Jeffrey Cohen. Outline only June 15, 1990
Typescript, corrected in autograph. Titled: In the Capital of the World: A Collage.1991
Typescript, incorporating scenes from the play "Make Up Your Mind," plus Appendix, lightly corrected. Titled: The Hocus Pocus Laundromat: Freethinker Papers
Typescript photocopy, incorporating scenes from the play "Make Up Your Mind," plus Appendix. Titled: The Hocus Pocus Laundromat: Freethinker Papers

Photocopy of corrected typescript, 2 copies. Labeled "Complete as of 2.8.91."
Fortitude: A short film. Typescript; teleplay by Stan Daniels, first draft, Oct. 30, 1991 several draft pages; photocopy from Playboy Sept. 1968
The Foster Portfolio. Outline of script, written by Jeremy Hole May 27, 1990
Galapagos. Introduction to Franklin Library edition
Girl Pool. Typescript and carbon typescript of play (see also: Short stories and articles: Girl Pool)
Galley proof. Corrected in autograph. Stamped "Master Proof...November 25, 1964"Nov. 25, 1964
Galley proof of God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater (published 1965) 1965
Three typescripts and photocopy of "God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater: A New Musical" by Howard Ashman, Alan Menken, and Dennis Green. Dated: Apr. 1, 1979, June 4, 1979, Sept. 4, 1979, undated
Grieve My Lord No More. Typescript of play
Typescript, corrected in autograph, of an early draft of the play in novel form. Additional pages of corrected typescript. Titled: The Fur-Lined Bouillon Cup 1971
Photocopy of early draft of play. Titled: The Fur-Lined Bouillon Cup, or a Woman Is Not an Electric Scoreboard
Two different typescript versions, corrected in autograph, of an early draft of the play. Titled: Penelope. Additional uncorrected or very lightly corrected typescript drafts.
Photocopies of Acts 2 and 3, two photographs of production and cover letter from Thomas A. Power of early version of play entitled: Penelopeas performed at University of Maine

Two different typescript versions, corrected in autograph, of an early draft of the play entitled: Something Borrowed. Additional uncorrected or very lightly corrected typescript drafts of various sections

Typescript photocopy, rev. 8/5/70 typescript, rev. 8/24/70 typescript, labeled "Final script October 12, 1970" heavily corrected in autograph; typescript, labeled "Final script October 12, 1970" lightly corrected in autograph; typescript, labeled "Revised final script 11/20/70" with photocopied and original corrections

Photocopy of a revised ending, with a photocopy of a letter for Vonnegut to Dusty Hughes, Apr. 12, 1977 typescript of another revised ending, with an original letter from Vonnegut to Don Farber, Jan. 8, 1981
Heidi Again. Two page synopsis and typescript of play
The Helmer Case. Nora. Play. Autograph pages; typescript; and mimeograph
Hey Earth--We're Watching You. Synopsis and proposed cast list for play by Vonnegut and Dick Feldman

Several early typescript drafts, entitled: Mary Kathleen O'Looney or Unacceptable Air. mostly rewrites of the beginning chapters, corrected in autograph 1979

Typescript, Mary Kathleen O'Looney (Or, Fats in a Windstorm). retitled: Jailbird by Vonnegut in autograph

The Sirens of Titan. 1959 Typescript. Corrected in autograph. Fifteen bundles of rolled-up leaves, with a few pages of typescript drafts. One bundle for Chap. 1-5, 7-9, 11, two for Chap. 6 and 12 [no Chap. 10]. Typescript of a new introduction, 1989.
Slapstick. Five typescripts of screenplay, lyrics to "Lonesome No More"

(play). Typescript of synopsis and revised script, dated Dec. 15, 1995 brochure/order form for performance in Munich; ticket stubs and stagebill for performance in Chicago at the Steppenwolf Theatre; undated clipping of review from the London Financial Times

Tom Edison's Shaggy Dog. Script adapted for radio by Bill Zucca
Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow. Script
Wampeters, Foma, and Granfalloons. Final draft, made up of typescript pages, magazine clippings, and photocopies, corrected throughout in autograph, with printer's notes in margins 1974
Welcome to the Monkey House. Script of Act I
The Windup Man. Three typescripts of television script
Introduction to story by Frank Conroy for Gentleman's Quarterly
Book reviews written by Vonnegut for the following: The Disney Version by Richard Schickel; The Triumph by John Kenneth Galbraith; Unless Peace Comes edited by Nigel Calder

scopecontent.p: Contains drafts, final typescripts, and related materials. Many accompanying envelopes are covered in Vonnegut's characteristic doodles; some list (in another hand) dates for submission of the story, and, if accepted, the amount paid by various magazines. Arranged alphabetically by title.

scopecontent.p: Contain the files of Donald C. Farber in his capacity as Vonnegut's lawyer and literary agent. Arranged alphabetically by work. Includes: correspondence, contracts, notes, and other materials. The correspondence includes requests to publish, translate, or produce on stage or film various works. "Notes" refers to Farber's and his secretaries' handwritten notes. (See also: I. General correspondence)

did.unittitle: Between Time and Timbuktu. Correspondence:1971- 1992; notes
Breakfast of Champions. Correspondence:1972-1995; contracts; notes; promotional material
Deadeye Dick. Correspondence:1981-1995; notes; promotional materials
Notes; promotional materials and playbill; Rosewater Partnership
Happy Birthday, Wanda June. Correspondence:1970-1994; contracts; notes; programs, poster, set plan & property plot
Hocus Pocus. Correspondence:1986-1995; notes; publicity schedule
Rage and Outrage. Correspondence: 1978; contracts; notes; story outlines
Wampeters, Foma, and Grandfalloons. Correspondence: 1969-1995; contracts; notes
Correspondence: 1972-1995; contracts; D.P.. tear-sheet; notes; TV series - cast and crew lists
Materials concerning contract negotiations and foreign publication rights, miscellaneous contracts, and royalty reports

note.p: Includes: "An account of the ancestry of Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. by an ancient friend of his family, Indianapolis, 1970"; passports; clippings; copies of entries to various biographical sources
"Thirteen haiku composed by James C. Adams, Jr., for the seventieth birthday of his uncle Kurt Vonnegut, Jr., November 11th, 1992..."

Includes: several original drawings by Vonnegut, catalog of his work, articles about his artwork, materials concerning an exhibition at the Margo Feiden Galleries in New York; two drawings of Vonnegut signed "GR81" (probably drawn from photographs).
Two copies and associated materials
(later: Cosby Bureau International). Includes materials pertaining to speaking engagements

Description, rules, correspondence, and diagrams in Vonnegut's hand for the boardgame G.H.Q. (General Headquarters) invented by Vonnegut. With the original typed draft of a letter to Mr. Saalfield at Saalfield Game Company in Ohio
Typescript, over 100 pages. Part of a novel by Vonnegut's ex-wife, Jane Cox
List of Board of Directors, November 1988

did.unittitle: Photocopy of Vonnegut's final high school report card and history of PS43. Both enclosed in letter from Robert Weide at "Whyaduck Productions" to Vonnegut May 18, 1994

Anthropology 220, 230, 345, 499 and unidentified classes. Worksheets, notes and papers with notes and doodles throughout; notes, assignments, and charts; papers and exams, some with teacher's comments and grades.
History 201. Syllabus and Problems. University of Chicago Bookstore, June 1945. 153 pages. Vonnegut's college textbook, with his annotations and doodles. Various related pages laid in

Thesis, tentatively titled "Mythologies of North American Nativistic Movements." Removed from binder. Summer, 1947. Notes, charts, annotated pages, with doodles throughout. Laid in are a couple of notes from his advisor and an outline for the project
Thesis "Fluctuations Between Good and Ill Fortune in Simple Tales" written at the Writer's Workshop at University of Iowa. Four copies October, 1965

note.p: Materials relating to membership
paid bills, investment information, life insurance, retirement trust, etc.
ephemera, including maps, Vonnegut's handwritten itineraries and schedules, tickets, visas, etc
(KV's uncle). Letter to Alex from Vonnegut, Nov. 28, 1947 accompanied by anecdote about it written by Vonnegut
(KV's brother). Material relating to his death, Apr. 25, 1997
(KV's son). Color photocopy of painting with description of why he paints
Materials relating to membership

Copies of family pictures (9); Vonnegut, et al. taken at breakfast at Gracie Mansion honoring President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, 1990; Vonnegut taken at United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, 1986; scrapbook: photographs taken at Vonnegut's 60th birthday celebration, Nov. 11, 1982; Bound volume: photographs taken in Prague, 1985; Scrapbook: "Vonneguts (from Aunt Raye's Scrapbook)," mostly clippings, a few photographs(see also: Box 23)
Mostly reviews of Vonnegut's books and some about him

Drama Desk Award, 1970-1971; Grammy Award nomination, 1973; The John Steinbeck Award, 1992; Man of the Year award from General Electric; recognition from Indiana Arts Commission, The New School, Phi Beta Kappa, and The American Civil Liberties Union; honorary degrees from Hobart and William Smith Colleges, University of Rhode Island, and University of Chicago, University of Evansville; Television-Radio Writers' Annual Award, Writers Guild of America for "Auf Wiedersehen, 1957-1958 (see also: Box 26)
The Freethinker's Calendar, 1989. Vonnegut's birthday noted on Nov. 11
photographs taken at Butler University, honorary degree presentation, May 11, 1996
Senior Portfolio, 1908, M.I.T. (yearbook)
Aunt Irma V. Lindener, interview with KV, Jr., May 3, 1984. Side 2: Aunt Irma and Richy
Grana/Vonnegut Requiem.

Jazz Section Interview - NPR. A concert and series of press conferences organized to bring attention the plight of the Jazz Section and it's struggle for cultural freedom in Czechoslovakia, International Jazz Coalition
